oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Black Girls Unknown: Sista Scholars Navigating and Countering Misogynoir in an Urban Alternative School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Edwards, Erica
Yett , AeYanna
Webb, Joi
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Black girlhood studies
Alternative schools
Urban Education
Humanizing Research
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This comparative and exploratory study considers Black girls’ navigational practices through an urban alternative school. Facilitated as a Project in Humanization (San Pedro & Kinloch, 2017), this study used kitchen table conversations as a primary method to resist Black girls’ invisibility in alternative school research and practice. Semi-structured interviews, field observations, and analytical memo writing were also used to collect the girls’ schooling histories and educators’ perceptions of Black girls’ needs. Findings evidence the pervasive logic of misogynoir in educators’ efforts to support Black girls and demonstrate the importance of centering positive self-concept to advance critically engaged work with Black girls. Further, the study evidences the need for educators to create learning spaces that are free from hegemonic standards prescribed by white supremacy. Action items toward realizing the visibility and humanity of Black girls in alternative schools and beyond are proposed.
